Course Description: This biophysics course shall delve into concepts of physics acting upon biomolecules, primarily proteins. From understanding protein folding to predicting 3-dimension structures from the 1-dimension sequence, the course shall involve assignments that shall give the students the neccessary knowledge to deal with structural problems.

Prerequisites.Mandatory: Basic knowledge of biology, chemistry, physics and python

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to understand the relation of protein evolution with its function and explain fundamental structural properties
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to decipher fundamentals forces acting upon biomolecules
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to extract meaningful Thermodynamic analysis and are able to explain the underlying connection with statistical physics for structure prediction
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students are able to apply statistical and statistical-mechanical ideas to a solve complex biological systems.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction to Statistical Mechanics and basic mathematics in biophysics
Electrostatics and other interactions in proteins & water, Secondary structure and amino acid properties
Free energy and the hydrophobic effect

Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments/Lab/Tutorials: Assignment: (1) where students will actually simulate protein/DNA or their interactions using computers.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Thermodynamics of structural transitions, folding & denaturation
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments/Lab/Tutorials: Assignment: (2) where students are going to simulate folding

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Insertion, Folding & Interactions of Membrane Proteins
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments/Lab/Tutorials: Assignment: (3) where students will actually predict protein structures using computers.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Secondary structure stability, helix-coil transitions & cooperativity
Statistical mechanics, the partition function, and first- order phase transitions

Textbook: Protein Physics A Course of Lectures by Alexei V. Finkelstein and Oleg B. Ptitsyn
Physical Biology of the Cell, Second Edition by Rob Phillips, Jane Kondev, Julie Theriot, and Hernan Garcia (Garland Science, 2012)
Introductory Biophysics by J. R. Claycomb and J.Q.P. Tran
